revision.text:
The '''''vagina loquens''''', or "talking vagina", is a significant tradition in literature and art, dating back to the ancient [[folklore]] [[Motif (folkloristics)|motif]] of the "talking cunt".<ref name=ozark>{{cite book|title=Unprintable Ozark Folksongs and Folklore: Blow the candle out|publisher=[[University of Arkansas Press]]|author=Vance Randolph, Gershon Legman |year=1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S93LdPw2KP0C&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=1557282374|pages=819–820}}</ref><ref name=Zizek>{{cite book|title=Organs without bodies: Deleuze and consequences|publisher=[[Routledge]]|author=Slavoj Zizek |year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pp6-1yQbgmgC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0415969212|page=173}}</ref> These tales usually involve [[vaginas]] talking due to the effect of magic or charms, and often admitting to their unchastity.<ref name=ozark/> Another tradition is a vagina that acquires the power of speech to play the role of [[informant]] and reveal a history of previous lovers.<ref>{{cite web|title=vagina loquens|url=http://www.definition-of.com/vagina%20loquens|publisher=Definition Of|accessdate=30 March 2012}}</ref>
Talking vaginas are an early theme in [[French literature]], most notably in the 13th century [[fabliau]] ''Le Chevalier qui faisoit parler les cons et les culs''<ref name=ozark/> and in ''[[Les bijoux indiscrets]]'', the first novel by [[Denis Diderot]]. Published anonymously in 1748, ''Les bijoux indiscrets'' (''The Indiscreet Jewels'') is an allegory that portrays [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]] as the sultan Mangogul of the Congo who owns a magic ring that makes women's genitals ("jewels") talk. A comparable ''trope'' that Diderot must have known is found in the ribald ''[[fabliau]]''.<ref name=ozark/>
In American literature, a talking vagina is featured in the [[Ozark]] folktale ''The Magic Walking Stick'',<ref name=ozark/> in which vaginas are made to act as informants. The talking vagina theme is the central trope of ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]''.<ref name=Zizek/>
In [[modern art]] the talking vagina theme is featured prominently in the works of [[Stephanie Sarley]] in a subset of her "Crotch Monster" series. The talking vagina characters are depicted as [[anthropomorphized]] [[vulvae]] reacting emotionally and engaging in various activities.<ref name="huffPostSSarley">{{Cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/stephanie-sarley-vagina-drawings_us_56e8912fe4b0860f99dae1a2 | title = You Can Start A Small Revolution Just By Drawing A Vagina | author = Priscilla Frank | publisher = The Huffington Post | accessdate = 2016-03-16 }}</ref>
In film, the [[pornographic movies]] ''[[Le Sexe qui parle]]'' (1975) and its sequel (1978), and its non-pornographic remake, ''[[Chatterbox (1977 film)|Chatterbox]]'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Shumate|first=Nathan|title=Chatterbox (1977)|url=http://www.coldfusionvideo.com/archives/chatterbox-1977/|publisher=Cold Fusion Reviews|accessdate=30 March 2012}}</ref> feature talking vaginas.
On television, [[Joan Rivers]] portrayed [[List_of_Drawn_Together_characters#Princess_Clara|Princess Clara]]'s talking vagina on ''[[Drawn Together]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Folklore]] [[Category:Pornography]] [[Category:Latin words and phrases]] [[Category:American literature]] [[Category:French literature]] [[Category:Vagina and vulva in art]] [[Category:Fictional body parts]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox building | name = Newby-McMahon Building | image = Newby-McMahon Building, 1919.JPG | image_alt = Newby-McMahon Building, c. 1919, also known as the "Worlds Littlest Skyscraper" | caption = | location = [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|33.9144|-98.4897|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | roof = {{convert|12.2|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 4 habitable floors | start_date = 1919 | completion_date = 1919 | opening = 1919 | building_type = Mixed-use | floor_area = {{convert|40|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} | cost = $200,000 | architect = Michael Beards | structural_engineer = J.D. McMahon | main_contractor = J.D. McMahon | references = <ref name=Bundy/><ref name=ARN19980820/><ref name=WFTRN20091230/><ref name=Stowers2008/> | embedded = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Newby–McMahon Building | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | designated_nrhp_type = February 4, 2004 | partof = [[Depot Square Historic District (Wichita Falls, Texas)|Depot Square Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 03001552<ref name="focus">{{Cite web |title=NPS Focus |work=National Register of Historic Places |url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=July 10, 2012}}</ref> }} }}
The '''Newby-McMahon Building''', commonly referred to as the '''world's littlest skyscraper''', is located at 701 La Salle (on the corner of Seventh and La Salle streets) in downtown [[Wichita Falls, Texas|Wichita Falls]], [[Texas]]. This late [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] style red brick and [[cast stone]] structure is {{convert|40|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall,<ref name=Bundy/> and its exterior dimensions are {{convert|18|ft|m|abbr=on}} deep and {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name=ARN19980820/><ref name=WFTRN20091230/> Its interior dimensions are approximately {{convert|12|ft|m|abbr=on}} by {{convert|9|ft|m|abbr=on}}, or approximately {{convert|108|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. Steep, narrow, internal stairways leading to the upper floors occupy roughly 25 percent of the interior area.<ref name=Bundy/><ref name=Stowers2008/>
Reportedly the result of a fraudulent investment scheme by a [[Confidence trick|confidence man]], the Newby-McMahon Building was a source of great embarrassment to the city and its residents after its completion in 1919. During the 1920s, the Newby-McMahon Building was featured in [[Robert Ripley]]'s ''[[Ripley's Believe It or Not!]]'' syndicated column as "the world's littlest skyscraper," a nickname that has stuck with it ever since. The Newby-McMahon Building is now part of the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Wichita County, Texas|Depot Square Historic District]] of Wichita Falls, a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark|Texas Historic Landmark]].
==Background== A large [[petroleum reservoir]] was discovered just west of the city of [[Burkburnett, Texas|Burkburnett]], a small town in [[Wichita County, Texas|Wichita County]], Texas in 1912.<ref name=Kelly1982/><ref name=Olien2002/><ref name=Hart2010/> Burkburnett and its surrounding communities became [[boomtown]]s, experiencing explosive growth of their populations and economies. By 1918, an estimated 20,000 new settlers had taken up residence around the lucrative [[oil field]], and many Wichita County residents became wealthy virtually overnight. As people streamed into the local communities in search of high-paying jobs, the nearby city of Wichita Falls began to grow in importance. Though it initially lacked the necessary infrastructure for this sudden increase in economic and industrial activity, Wichita Falls was a natural choice to serve as the local logistical hub, being the seat of Wichita County. Because office space was lacking, major stock transactions and [[mineral rights]] deals were conducted on street corners and in tents that served as makeshift headquarters for the new oil companies.<ref name=WFTRN20010725/>
==Proposal and blueprints== The Newby-McMahon Building is a four-story brick building located near the railroad depot in downtown Wichita Falls, built in 1906 by Augustus Newby (1855–1909),<ref name=WDT1909/><ref name=TSOT0721/> a director of the Wichita Falls and Oklahoma City Railway Company.<ref name=OK1898/> The oil-rig construction firm of J.D. McMahon, a [[Landman (oil worker)|petroleum landman]] and [[structural engineer]] from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], was one of seven tenants whose offices were based in the original Newby Building.<ref name=Bundy/><ref name=TSOT0721/>
According to local legend,<ref name=Kelso2007>{{cite book|title=Texas Curiosities: Quirky Characters, Roadside Oddities & Other Offbeat Stuff|edition=3rd|chapter=North Texas|page=112|author=Kelso J|publisher=Morris Book Publishing|location=Kearney, Nebraska|year=2007|isbn=978-0-7627-4109-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gW9ye7wu0E0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Texas+Curiosities:+Quirky+Characters,+Roadside+Oddities+%26+Other+Offbeat+Stuff}}</ref> when McMahon announced in 1919 that he would build a highrise annex to the Newby Building as a solution to the newly wealthy city's urgent need for office space, investors were eager to invest in the project.<ref name=WFTRN20010725/><ref name=TAC20000915/> McMahon collected $200,000 (US ${{Inflation|US|200000|1919|r=-5|fmt=c}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}}) in [[Financial capital|investment capital]] from this group of naive investors, promising to construct a highrise office building across the street from the [[St. James Hotel (Wichita Falls, Texas)|St. James Hotel]].<ref name=WFTRN20091230/><ref name=Stowers2008/>
The key to McMahon's swindle, and his successful defense in the ensuing lawsuit, was that he never verbally stated that the actual height of the building would be {{convert|480|ft|m}}.<ref name=ARN19980820/><ref name=Fodors2008/><ref name=WFTRN20021208/> The proposed skyscraper depicted in the blueprints that he distributed (and which were approved by the investors) was clearly labeled as consisting of four floors and {{convert|480|in|m}}.<ref name=Pohlen2006/>
==Construction and ensuing legal battle== McMahon used his own construction crews to build the McMahon Building on the small, unused piece of property next to the Newby Building, without obtaining prior consent from the owner of the property, who lived in Oklahoma.<ref name=WFTRN20021208/> As the building began to take shape, the investors realized they had been swindled into purchasing a four-story edifice that was only {{convert|40|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall, rather than the {{convert|480|ft|m|abbr=on}} structure they were expecting.
They brought a lawsuit against McMahon, but to their dismay, the real estate and construction deal was declared legally binding by a local judge – as McMahon had built exactly according to the blueprints they had approved, no legal remedy was available for the deceived investors.<ref name=Stowers2008/> They did recover a small portion of their investment from the elevator company, which refused to honor the contract after they learned of the confidence trick. No stairway was installed in the building upon its initial completion, as none was included in the original blueprints. Rather, a ladder was employed to gain access to the upper three floors.<ref name=ARN19980820/> By the time construction was complete, McMahon had left Wichita Falls and perhaps even Texas, taking with him the balance of the investors' money.<ref name=Pohlen2006/>
==Early occupancy and subsequent abandonment== Upon its completion and opening in 1919, the Newby-McMahon Building was an immediate source of great embarrassment to the city and its residents.<ref name=WFTRN20010327/><ref name=WFTRN20040506/> The ground floor had six desks representing the six different companies that occupied the building as its original tenants.<ref name=WFTRN20021208/> Throughout most of the 1920s, the building housed only two firms.<ref name=WFTRN20021208/> During the 1920s, the Newby-McMahon Building was featured in Robert Ripley's ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' syndicated column as "the world's littlest skyscraper", which is a name that has stuck with it ever since.<ref name=ARN19980820/><ref name=TSOT0721/><ref name=WFTRN19990917/>
The oil industry would ultimately prove to be a [[resource curse]] to Wichita Falls, and the [[Texas Oil Boom]] ended only a few years later. The building was vacated, boarded up, and virtually forgotten in 1929 as the [[Great Depression]] struck North Texas and office space became relatively inexpensive to lease or purchase.<ref name=Stowers2008/> A fire gutted the building in 1931, rendering it unusable for a number of years.<ref name=WFTRN20021208/>
After the Great Depression, the building housed a succession of tenants, including barber shops and cafés. The building changed hands many times and was scheduled for demolition on several occasions, but escaped this fate apparently because a sufficient number of local residents came to its defense.<ref name=TSOT0721/> It was eventually deeded to the city of Wichita Falls. As the building continued to deteriorate, in 1986 the city gave the building to the Wichita County Heritage Society (WCHS), with the hope that it would eventually be restored, making it a viable part of the Depot Square Historic District.<ref name=ARN19980820/><ref name=Stowers2008/>
==Purchase and renovation== By 1999, the Newby-McMahon Building had proved to be an excessive burden on the limited capital reserves of the WCHS.<ref name=WFTRN19990810/><ref name=WFTRN19991018/><ref name=WFTRN19991020/><ref name=WFTRN20000806/> The following year, the city council hired the local architectural firm of Bundy, Young, Sims & Potter to stabilize the crumbling structure, amid steadily growing talk of demolishing the building.<ref name=Stowers2008/> Dick Bundy and his partners became fascinated with the history and legacy of the building; they arranged a partnership with Marvin Groves Electric, another local business, to purchase the building.<ref name=Bundy/> In December 2000, the city council voted to allow the WCHS to sell the building to Marvin Groves for $3,748.<ref name=WFTRN20001216/>
On June 11, 2003, a storm swept through Wichita Falls, bringing gusts of wind as strong as {{convert|97|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. A 15-ft (4.6-m) section of brick wall from the McMahon Building complex was knocked down.<ref name=WFTRN20030614/> The damage from this storm was repaired, but full restoration of the building and the adjacent Newby Building was delayed until late 2005. In June of that year, the City Council granted $25,000 in funds from the city's [[tax increment financing]] fund, to be invested in the restoration of the McMahon Building.<ref name=WFTRN20050619/><ref name=WFTRN20050622/> Restoration of the building is estimated to have cost more than $254,000, the remainder of which was paid by the owners (Bundy, Young, Sims & Potter, Inc. and Marvin Groves Electric).<ref name=WFTRN20050619/><ref name=WFTRN20050622/>
==Current status== <!-- {{Tone|section|date=March 2018}} -->[[File:Wichita Falls October 2015 18 (Hello Again! and "world's littlest skyscraper").jpg|thumb|alt=|The Newby-McMahon Building and the Hello Again! storefront in October 2015]] [[File:Newby-McMahon Building-02.jpg|thumb|alt=|Plaque attached to the Newby-McMahon Building, also known as the "world's littlest skyscraper". This plaque refers to the building adjacent to the "skyscraper" which was completed in 1906, the "skyscraper" building was completed in 1919.]]
With the passage of time, the Newby-McMahon Building has become a monument to a long-gone era. It has survived tornadoes, a fire, and decades of neglect to stand as a monument to the greed, genius, graft, and gullibility of the [[oil boom]] days of [[North Texas]].<ref name=OConnor1986/> The building is currently part of the Depot Square Historic District of Wichita Falls,<ref name=TSOT0721/> which has been declared a [[Recorded Texas Historic Landmark|Texas Historic Landmark]] and listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].<ref name=WFTRN19990319/><ref>{{Cite web |title=Depot Square Historic District |work=Texas Historic Sites Atlas |publisher=[[Texas Historical Commission]] |url=http://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/viewform.asp?atlas_num=2003001552 |accessdate=July 10, 2012}}</ref> The building has never met the criteria for the definition of a [[skyscraper]],<ref name=ESN24419/> nor even that of a "[[Tower block|highrise]]" building.<ref name=ESN18727/> After its renovation, the building was home to an antiques dealership, the Antique Wood, which opened in 2006 on the ground floor.<ref name=WFTRN20050728/><ref name=WFTRN20070326/> Since 2013, besides being a local tourist attraction, a furniture and home décor consignment boutique, Hello Again has occupied the entire building. At times, floors of the skyscraper have been subleased to various local artisans.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGinnis|first1=Judith|title=Downtown retail future gets boost from the past|publisher=Wichita Falls Times Record News|date=Feb 28, 2016}}</ref>
The Newby-McMahon Building is among several historic buildings featured in the documentary film ''Wichita Falls: The Future of Our Past'', a retrospective analysis of the city's architectural past produced in 2006 by Barry Levy, a public information officer with the city of Wichita Falls.<ref name=WFTRN20061202/> <!--A document written by Delores Mathews and updated by Ruth E. Reuther gives more of the history of the building.-->

'''Yamal Iri''' (in Russian ''Ямал Ири'', meaning "Grandfather of Yamal")<ref>[http://www.yamaliri.ru/ Yamal Iri website] {{ru icon}}</ref> is a character associated with [[Christmas]] in the [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug]], [[Russia]], a counterpart of [[Ded Moroz]] and [[Santa Claus]].
The character was introduced in 2007 on an initiative of several tourism organizations of Yamal. His image was based on a contest of children's [[drawing]]s and works of [[Decorative arts|decorative art]]. The character was also supplied with a legend, based on traditions of the [[Northern indigenous peoples of Russia]].<ref>[http://www.yamaliri.ru/index.php?do=cat&category=ist&PHPSESSID=d91ea98c32f17e25709d145142d239fd History and Legend of Yamal Iri]</ref>
==Story of Yamal Iri== According to legend, Yamal Iri works all year long, travels a lot, and helps people in various ways. Не teaches people to do things right and conducts the ritual ceremony of joining travelers to the Northern Brotherhood in the spot of [[Arctic Circle]] [[stela]] in [[Salekhard]].<ref>[http://festivals.iloveindia.com/christmas/characters/yamal-iri.html Yamal Iri Christmas Character - History, Legends & Myths]</ref> Yamal Iri's vestments are done in the national traditions style of the North. His magic rune-covered staff is not his only attribute; he also possesses a [[drum]] which he utilizes regularly to conduct his rituals. The drum is made up of [[reindeer]] skin and wood, following the ancient [[Nenets people|Nenets]] technology. The drum's beetle is made of [[birch]]. It is covered by reindeer fur. Its sound is supposed to drive away evil spirits, to give a charge of cheerfulness and positive energy, and bestows chances for good and happiness. He is both gentle in speech, and very self-confident and self-assured in his strength.
